room in the basement here and also was influenced quite a bit by professor pam heinz who's still here in

and you'll see bits of both of that in today's talk so that's enough about me that was a good introduction i want to tell you
about a guy named dallas dallas is an electrical engineer
he uh he was working a few years ago at willow garage as an electrical engineer and he he faced a dilemma his family was
in indiana but his job was in california and until recently the only solution was to choose one or the other or waste a
lot of time and money flying back and forth so dallas chose his family he lives in indiana and he used uh he continued to
work for willow using sort of the traditional teleconferencing options that are available today video chat
um uh sort of you know uh remote collaboration tools but he felt
like over time his sense of presence was starting to attenuate uh he felt like his connection
to his his colleagues was weakening he missed informal gatherings he felt like he was out of the loop on some
things i know people would forget to ask him questions they would forget to keep him in the loop so yeah so in short he
was losing his sense of presence and um luckily he was working at a place that had a lot of things he could put
together a solution and with one of his co-workers there a guy named kurt myers he put together a prototype for remote
presence which was called tex eye tex eye seemed pretty cool
a lot more people got involved with the project at that point including myself and we went through many rounds of prototyping and user study i'm going to

through our research so being launched last fall from our company suitable technologies we believe it's the best remote presence device
that you can buy and for dallas what this does is this technology gives back his sense of presence you know now he can hang out at

people to talk in person sometimes when they don't want to be found and he can see things from all angles
he's not just stuck on a wall he's not stuck on a desk he can move around he can see things from all angles as if he were there in
person and he has a great quote he says living in indiana and working in silicon valley
with beam is isn't the best of both worlds it is both worlds and this is really how he sees it
um so what i'd like to do today is review some research on remote presence uh even if it wasn't called that yet
when the research was being done talk about why we designed beam the way we did the research that we've done since

pilot and everyone else is a local the people who are interacting with her through the device we refer to them as locals
so beam really consists of three pieces the remote presence device itself this dock which is for charging and then
the software that the pilot installs on their computer in order to control um and use the system
and you'll see examples of all this through the through the video some other stats it has a 17 inch lcd display it's 5 feet
2 inches tall or 158 centimeters has two hd cameras you can see how they're stacked to give you a view both
in front and below microphone array above the screen speaker below two wi-fi radios and
top speed of 1.5 meters per second or about little over three miles per hour
so this is the punch line at the end of this video is that um
it turns out she was home the whole time traveling around the world working with her team
in asia america and everything and but she was actually comfortably at home in her own office
so yeah if you want to see that video again it's at suitabletech.com the benefits of working remotely
also sometimes called teleworking or telecommuting are pretty well documented i think at this point
um there was a um some research came out of stanford actually in economics department last year nicholas bloom uh
did the largest most empirical study yet on this topic uh with a chinese travel agency
called travel agency called c-trip um where they did an experimental um
where they grouped um the workers into people who were able to work at home and those who had to come into the office and found you know outside the margin of
error that people were not only more productive and happier but also healthier when they were able to work at home and that was
you know so and that was in terms of reduced number of sick days so it's like a win-win-win um and uh it means you can
live anywhere you can cut down and travel and other costs so why doesn't everyone work from home if that if it's so great well
there are several reasons some of the most commonly cited are things like um
some tasks are difficult to do this way you know to be honest sometimes you need you know to be able to use your thumbs or other things that are hard to do
remotely with technology available today sometimes there's a stigma or a
suspicion of not working as hard when you're at home depends on the company culture and one of the most commonly cited
things is the importance of face-to-face communication and the reason i have a picture of yahoo up here many of you may have you know heard about there was some
news earlier this year where they basically put a total ban on any kind of remote working inside the company and
that was one of the things that was cited in their internal memo the importance of face-to-face communication so that's why remote presence is so
exciting um to us and i think it's a really transformative technology because you can get all of these benefits of
benefits of being able to work remotely you know being happier being more productive being able to have more
control over your time and where you live but also still preserve the the rich face-to-face interaction that is so
important too um people have pondered the possibilities
of remote presence for centuries and perhaps longer so i'm going to do like 400 years of philosophy in two minutes
um so starting with descartes for example had this concept of an evil demon with the power to
intercept um your senses and present arbitrary information to you to basically trick
you into thinking there's a world an alternate world is that's not the one that actually exists this is similar to the brain in a vat thought experiment
famous one in philosophy they're both basically a man-in-the-middle attack on your brain
saying you don't know if you're if your brain's in a body or if it's in a jar somewhere hooked up to some sensors and some stimuli
but they but they both raise the question of what it actually means to believe you're anywhere and in some sense the reason i'm bringing this up is
in some sense what we're trying to do with remote presence is attempt to provide enough sensory
information to your brain to make you think that you are somewhere else at least to some degree maybe for the purposes of the work that you're trying
to do also i wanted to mention a phenomenologist such as heidegger
encourage us to see the difference between perceiving objects as they actually are and the purpose
and perceiving them as fulfilling a purpose so in the language of heidegger we want remote presence to be a ready uh
ready to hand technology not present at hand you don't want to see a remote presence device and just see it as a collection of components and pieces of
technology you want to see what it's for which is actually transporting you or transporting someone else from one place
to another and finally i wanted to mention the the blind man blind man's cane example from merlot ponte which is
suggests that um you know when a blind man finding his way through the world by using a cane he's not so much
feeling the wood of the cane you know the wood grain and the specific makeup of what the how the cane is composed
what he's feeling the world through the cane and in a very similar way we want people to experience the world through a
remote presence device so we need to replicate we need to reproduce that as faithfully as we can
irving goffman's book from 1959 the presentation of self in everyday life tremendously influential book in
computer mediated communication and remote presence is definitely no exception uh goffman suggests that all
social interaction is a performance um so in every interaction that you have in life you're
trying to present yourself in the way that you want others to perceive you and uh this applies um as i said all
kinds of interactions but perhaps none more literally than remote presence because you're literal you you are
literally on camera while you're using it and so if you're using this kind of technology all day long
um you know a pilot station is kind of like a mini tv studio since this is the way people are going to perceive you you
start to care about things like how's my lighting what's the acoustic property of of the room i'm in how's my camera how's
my camera positioned do i have good microphones and stuff that you don't really have to normally have to worry about
in person but um you're much more conscious of this if you use remote presence
um so in the 1980s uh researchers started building systems that more closely resemble the kind of remote
presence technology that we see today uh the media spaces project at xerox park for example created a connection between
the lab in palo alto and and another one in portland using real-time audio and video
and these projects saw really saw the importance of informal communication between team members and and saw many
similar uses that we've seen with remote presence and with beam today such as impromptu conversations
being able to find people as i mentioned this was very important for dallas creating more informal awareness of each other
um and then going forward a few years there was a paper from holland and stornetta called beyond being there that i believe
was really ahead of its time and it's it's interesting because it's a difficult one for people like me as a technology enthusiast to really read and
appreciate because what they say and what they really prove in the paper is that um remote people will always be at
a disadvantage with the kind of technology that we have no matter how faithfully it reproduces the experience
unless it's good enough that people who are local also have a benefit for in using it
so um that's why that's why the paper is called beyond being there it's not just being there it's actually you need to go
beyond that you need to look for needs that are not being met in physical proximity and focus on those and i'll
come back to this a little bit um with our research on beam i also wanted to mention the the olson's judith and gary
olsen wrote on this theme several years later um showing that new technology hasn't
actually improved distance work as much as everyone thinks it has and they describe something called
tightly coupled work which is work that requires a lot of frequent communication has a lot of ambiguity and show that
remote technologies don't support most of the features that are so important to this type of work and there are several things that they
list but you know you know some of the most important are shared local context between
collaborators having informal time having individual control with the current technology that really doesn't
exist nonetheless in the early part of the
last decade people started to prototype these kinds of systems as the as the technology started to support it more
and more on the far left you see something called prop or personal roving presence from john canyon eric paulus at berkeley um
they even tried blimps that's what the giant eyeball is and then by reality was a project at hp
labs from norm jupi's lab which was a highly immersive take on remote presence this is the pilot room that you see here
as kind of a wrap around screen um they really spared no expense and it was uh it was really interesting system
at that time and of course we're not the only ones working on this today as well this this team at microsoft research for example
has built something they call the embedded social proxy which is very similar to a beam except that you can't drive it um
and it's targeted at the hub and satellite kind of team namely one person is remote from the
rest of the people in a local site and they found some results that are actually really similar to what we've
seen with beam such as stronger social connections increased attention and affinity
and increased participation in meetings and they've published some of this work you can read some of their findings
so with that as background before i go any further i'd like to present our definition of remote presence
it's it's kind of a new term it's really not telepresence it's not robotics it's something different real presence refers
to a system or device that enables people separated by distance to collaborate communicate
and understand each other as if they shared the same physical space without losing effectiveness over time and that
last part is really really important and to put it another way it's something that you can rely on every day you can
rely on it to do your job yeah sure
um for remote presence all of these things so i was just going to give some some examples of things that are similar

it's easy to be forgotten when you can't be seen so if this is the only way that you're interacting with your team you know over time you know there are going

factors of um tightly coupled work that just that frustration builds over time and it's just not good enough

so to try to um make the the results a little more
concise we've come up with what we believe are six core principles of what it takes to have remote presence
and initially our rule of thumb was we want to be able to do what a human can do we want to reproduce that as reliably as
possible but you know as i said earlier we've learned through this research and maybe we would have learned if we
surveyed the literature a little bit more up front that actually we do need to go beyond being there in some important ways and i'll go through each

you can keep up with other people as they're walking you're not going to be stymied by a pencil on the floor uh or or even furniture that's in your way you
can push it out of your way so if you're going to have remote presence it's important to be able to do the same thing
this is just a quick demonstration of some of the physical capabilities of a beam you can push chairs you can go over wires you can

on the lighter side of things we recently converted one of our one of our offices into a makeshift soccer field

but in general wherever wherever people can go beam can go

is is really an impediment to feeling remotely present it makes you dependent on them so for example it's very important that

that's good but they often forget to unmute before they start speaking again and that's very frustrating because you

if you start talking and you're muted this thing will start to flicker red give you an indication that hey you're talking but no one's hearing you and that has
almost entirely resolved this problem now people stop complaining about this so much and
we're really excited that that made such a big difference

if you go in there with another person you have to scream to each other to be hurt but if you go in there in a beam

would have never guessed two people are in the server room with somebody in a beam they're screaming to each other to

this is one where if i had a choice i would prefer to go into that server room in a beam than going physically yeah so
